awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Assessing the Capability of TEMPO Geostationary Satellite Observations of Formaldehyde to Constrain Volatile Organic Compound Emissions from Western U.S. Wildfire Smok
awd_abstract_narration:
Wildfires emit toxic trace gases and particular matters into the atmosphere, substantially impacting air quality, particularly in the western U.S. The project aims to contribute to the temporal observing strategy of a planned satellite for monitoring volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions from wildfires in near real-time. This project will potentially lead to better air quality forecast for many western EPSCoR states like Montana, Idaho, Wyoming, Nevada, and Utah, and thus would benefit millions of people exposed to wildfire smoke. The Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) geostationary satellite is planned for launch in 2022, providing key tropospheric composition measurements, including formaldehyde (HCHO) at unprecedentedly high spatial and temporal resolution. This proposed research will explore how the planned TEMPO formaldehyde observations could constrain VOC emissions from wildfire smoke in the western U.S., and to optimize TEMPO observing strategy for episodic wildfire events. Through the collaborative visit to the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory (SAO), we will develop new research skills in satellite remote sensing at the University of Montana (UM) that will provide a unique strength to understand organic emissions from the land surface. 

Specific tasks are designed to incorporate opportunities to strengthen the collaboration with the SAO and TEMPO science team and build the capacities of satellite remote sensing research at UM: (a) generating the synthetic TEMPO HCHO column data, (b) applying a high resolution adjoint-based inversion using synthetic data over western U.S., and (c) evaluating inversion results with independent airborne and ground field data for specific fire events. The results will inform TEMPO temporal observing strategy for exceptional wildfires and provide a guide for other episodic events such as dust outbreaks. The synthetic TEMPO data and the inversion results will be evaluated by independent field campaigns primarily focused on wildfire emissions (WE-CAN, FIREX-AQ, and Mt. Bachelor Observatory). It is expected that the comparison and validation will improve our knowledge on the uncertainties of satellite retrievals, and ultimately the VOC emissions from wildfires. This research will focus on fires in the western U.S., and results will be informative for other regions in the U.S. and around the world, and also for other pollution emissions that evolve at higher temporal resolution. By engaging in the TEMPO's pre-launch research, the proposed project not only will potentially transform the PI's career trajectory for the lifespan of the satellite, but also improve the UM's long-term competitiveness in environmental and ecological research. This project will bring the next generation of earth observing system to Montana and could benefit regional science communities and air quality regulators for various applications in air pollution, wildfire, forestry, ecology, public health, and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wildfires emit toxic trace gases and particular matters into the atmosphere, substantially impacting air quality, particularly in the western U.S. The Tropospheric Emissions: Monitoring of Pollution (TEMPO) geostationary satellite is planned for launch in 2023, providing critical tropospheric composition measurements, including formaldehyde (HCHO), unprecedentedly high spatial and temporal resolution. The project aims to understand better the uncertainty of satellite retrievals of formaldehyde in fire-influenced environments. The overall goal is to explore how the planned TEMPO formaldehyde observations could constrain VOC emissions from wildfire smoke in the western U.S. Through collaboration with the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory (SAO), we develop new research skills in satellite remote sensing at the University of Montana (UM) to provide a unique strength to understand organic emissions from the land surface.

Intellectual Merit:

We generate the TEMPO synthetic observations using a high-resolution GEOS-Chem simulation as a nature run. The synthetic data is then used to examine TEMPO HCHO vertical column density (VCD) uncertainties in fire smoke-influenced environments, focusing on a case study in the western US. TEMPO synthetic observations show clear enhancements of pyrogenic emissions of HCHO VCD over the west of the US in July 2018, reflecting that the nature run captures the considerable influence on wildfire smoke that summer, and that the synthetic operational VCD can detect such emissions. Compared to the true VCD, we find that the operational retrieval errors are about 20-60 % in the fire source regions and >90% in the western US's low/no smoke areas. The more significant retrieval errors in low/no smoke regions are due to the low abundance of VCD in the western US. Finally, we investigate the BB impacts on the HCHO retrievals by quantifying the effect of both high aerosol loading and the fire shape profile on the air mass factor (AMF) estimation, which are part of the error sources in VCD. We find that explicit aerosol correction is critical for improving the quality of HCHO retrievals in fire conditions. 

Broader Impacts:

This project helped train 1 Ph.D. student and one postdoc researcher from historically underrepresented groups. In addition, the project helped develop new research capabilities in remote sensing of atmospheric composition at the University of Montana. The materials generated from the project, such as satellite images for trace gas abundance during wildfires, are incorporated into the PI’s undergraduate and graduate courses in Environmental and Atmospheric Chemistry. The science learned from here for better satellite monitoring of air pollution will potentially lead to a better air quality forecast for many western states exposed to wildfire smoke.
